item.title: Ticket #1148 (can't navigate beyond first 20 comments in edit-comments.php) created
item.dc:creator: tor
item.description: There is no way to browse through old comments in 1.5, only the first 20 are displayed. A "Next 20" or something to that effect would be useful.

item.title: Ticket #958 (Comment feed for a single post shows only first 10 comments) updated
item.dc:creator: ringmaster
item.description:
If a post ID isn't supplied to the pre-patch code, the comments are already returned in descending (most recent at top) order. The single-post comments should do the same, don't you think?

If we wanted to change that behavior, adding an array_reverse($comments) around line 47 would fix both cases quite handily after the patch is applied.

item.title: Ticket #958 (Comment feed for a single post shows only first 10 comments) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Should the feed be presented in descending order though? Do we need to flip them back to ascending once the query is made?

item.title: Ticket #1147 (calls to plugin hooks are inconsistent) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1147 (calls to plugin hooks are inconsistent) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Although the wp_head hook can be called with <?php wp_head(); ?>, the equivalent <?php wp_footer ();?> does not exist. A consistent method of inserting plugin hooks (EITHER with template functions OR with 'do_action') should be established, since mixing the two methods is unnecessarily confusing.

Try this to change the user level: Back-up your db and try changing the user level via phpMyAdmin. This might help though it describes how to change the admin password and not a user's level: ​http://www.tamba2.org.uk/wordpress/phpmyadmin/ If in doubt, don't try but ask: ​http://wordpress.org/support hth Christian

edited on: 03-21-05 12:13

item.title: Ticket #1103 (Move RSS feed update for dashboard to pseudo cron) updated
item.dc:creator: jminard
item.description: It could be moved to the "shutdown" hook which utilizes the php function <a href="​http://us3.php.net/manual/en/function.register-shutdown-function.php">register_shutdown_function()</a> function. These calls happen after the script is done sending data to the client. However, the only issue with doing it this way is that the data on that page will not be updated until the next page load. Not such a big deal IMO though as most people aren't sitting on the edge of their seats waiting to read what's going on.

item.title: Ticket #1017 (Suggestion: Patch to allow feed templates) updated
item.dc:creator: darkcanuck
item.description:
I concur on this one - was about to add it to Mosquito myself.

Custom feed templates (whether in TEMPLATEPATH or wp-content) would allow people to customize metadata in each feed. Having it replaced by a plugin runs into the issue of two plugins competing for control over the feed output. By using a custom template then the tags from each plugin can exist together without extra headaches.

See also bug 1145 for another request for feed customization: ​http://mosquito.wordpress.org/view.php?id=1145

item.title: Ticket #1146 (Feeds don't use the_content when strlen(content) == 0) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1146 (Feeds don't use the_content when strlen(content) == 0) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: When a post->content is empty, the feeds use the_excerpt_rss instead of the_content. This can produce problems if plugins add stuff to the content (for example from custom fields), because the post->content check doesn't find any content and uses the_excerpt_rss and so the the_content hook isn't run at all. It might be better to fetch the content with running the hook and check wether the result is empty, instead.

item.description: Extension to the WordPress Plugin API that allows plugin developers to add metadata in RSS/ATOM feeds, as described in my proposal at ​http://www.fabriziotarizzo.org/wiki/Wikka/ProposalWordPressAPIExtension

item.title: Ticket #1144 (REQUEST_URI may be encoded but PATH_INFO, get_option('home') are not) updated
item.dc:creator: lev
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1144 (REQUEST_URI may be encoded but PATH_INFO, get_option('home') are not) created
item.dc:creator: lev
item.description:
Say someone is using unix style home directories in the blog url, like ​http://www.example.com/~frank is the blog home page.

1.) Telnet into example.com port 80. 2.) Type in the http request "GET /~frank/ HTTP/1.0", hit enter twice after typing that in. 3.) The resulting web page that comes out on the screen has the navigation link to get to the next page look like "​http://example.com/~frank/page/2/". This is fine.

4.) However, telnet back into example.com port 80. 5.) Type in this http request, "GET /%7Efrank/ HTTP/1.0", then hit enter twice. 6.) The resulting web page has a navigation link to get to the next page that looks like "​http://example.com/~frank/%7Efrank/page/2/". This is a problem.

item.title: Ticket #1143 (Permalinks not updated after blog location changes) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1143 (Permalinks not updated after blog location changes) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: If you set up a WP blog at, say www.example.com/wp and later decide you want to have it at www.example.com, you go and edit the blog location in the options. But if you've set up a permalink structure earlier, the permalinks completely stop working when you change the blog location.

item.title: Ticket #1142 (Need hooks for add_link and modify_link) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1142 (Need hooks for add_link and modify_link) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description:
For a plugin I was thinking of doing, I would need hooks for adding a link, and modifying a link. Preferably this would be called after the link is in the database and would pass the ID of the link.

More links == more plugin possibilties == less stuff that has to be put into core.

item.title: Ticket #1141 (link_added_date column for links) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1141 (link_added_date column for links) created
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: The "links" feature in WordPress could be used to run a nice little links log, except for the fact that it doesn't store the date/time when the link was added, so you can't do any month/year archives.

item.title: Ticket #1140 (Dashboard "Writing Options" wording suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: MC_incubus
item.description: I think you're absolutely right. I've uploaded a patch with the phrasing change... we'll see how the suits like it. ;-)

item.title: Ticket #1140 (Dashboard "Writing Options" wording suggestion) updated
item.dc:creator: firefly4wp
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #1140 (Dashboard "Writing Options" wording suggestion) created
item.dc:creator: firefly4wp
item.description:
What about changing:

"When you publish a new post WordPress can notify site update services."

to

"When you publish a new post WordPress automatically notifies the following site update services."

This makes it clearer to new users that this automatic notification is switched on by default.
